content.question:
For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

A student conducts an experiment to determine the value of <math alttext="delta H naught of solution" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msubsup><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mi>s</mi><mi>o</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>ln</mi></mstyle><mo>⁡</mo></mrow><mrow><mo>°</mo></mrow></msubsup></mrow></mstyle></math> for the dissolution of <math alttext="N a C 2 H 3 O 2, solid" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <msub> <mrow> <mtext>NaC</mtext> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>2</mn> </mrow> </msub> <msub> <mrow> <mtext>H</mtext> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>3</mn> </mrow> </msub> <msub> <mrow> <mtext>O</mtext> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>2</mn> </mrow> </msub> <mo>(</mo> <mi>s</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>. The student dissolves <math alttext="10.0 grams " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="N a C 2 H 3 O 2, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NaC</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in room-temperature water in a beaker and measures the temperature over time. The data are given in the graph above.

(a) The student touches the side of the beaker after the dissolution has occurred and observes that it is cold. What experimental evidence is consistent with the student's observation?

frqParts.text:
For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

A student conducts an experiment to determine the value of <math alttext="delta H naught of solution" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msubsup><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mi>s</mi><mi>o</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>ln</mi></mstyle><mo>⁡</mo></mrow><mrow><mo>°</mo></mrow></msubsup></mrow></mstyle></math> for the dissolution of <math alttext="N a C 2 H 3 O 2, solid" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <msub> <mrow> <mtext>NaC</mtext> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>2</mn> </mrow> </msub> <msub> <mrow> <mtext>H</mtext> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>3</mn> </mrow> </msub> <msub> <mrow> <mtext>O</mtext> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>2</mn> </mrow> </msub> <mo>(</mo> <mi>s</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>. The student dissolves <math alttext="10.0 grams " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="N a C 2 H 3 O 2, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NaC</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in room-temperature water in a beaker and measures the temperature over time. The data are given in the graph above.

(a) The student touches the side of the beaker after the dissolution has occurred and observes that it is cold. What experimental evidence is consistent with the student's observation?

(b) Is the dissolution of <math alttext="N a C 2 H 3 O 2, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mi>N</mi><mi>a</mi><msub><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mi>O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mstyle><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> endothermic or exothermic? Justify your answer in terms of the flow of energy between the system and surroundings.

(c) The student calculated the energy change for the dissolution to be <math alttext="4600 joules" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4600</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>J</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Based on this value, calculate <math alttext="delta H naught of solution " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msubsup><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mtext>soln</mtext></mstyle><mo>⁡</mo></mrow><mrow><mo>°</mo></mrow></msubsup></mrow></mstyle></math> in <math alttext="kilojoules per mole" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>kJ/mol</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

skill.text: 5.D: Identify information presented graphically to solve a problem.
